column2: All Fimir Mearghs are acomppained by a noxious mist that demoralises and poisons their enemies. Skattach is no exception.
The caster opens a rift into the Realm oF Chaos and binds a pack of Bloodletters to their will.

At the tip of this magical staff rests an ancient Fimir artifact known as "Balor's Eye" a magically preserved eye said to belong to the myterious Fimir god, able to open a rift into the Realm of Chaos and suck all of the user's enemies within.
An ancient but effective tactic, warriors stand shoulder to shoulder, holding their shields against their neighbours, creating a formidable wall of shields.
Sobering up Aragand might not always be the best idea, but you might learn a thing or two about him...
Heavy drinking leads to a heavy toll, withdrawal. It is inevitable that Aragand will return to the bottle, but for now, heroic deeds await!
Just a sip, just one drop, just to dull the pain...
A Bladesinger’s dance may start as a mesmerising, graceful pirouette, but always ends as a violent maelstrom of slicing, gashing slaughter!
What beauty and violence there is in the dance? A flurry of blades and a certain savagery of intent...
The wending and twisting of the Wardancers hardens their spirits and their bodies against would-be attackers.
The Wardancer threads and loops, contorting to create an ethereal fabric that turns aside arrows and bolts.
Legles's friendship comes with some benefits.
Giblit would very much like to see tomorrow.
[[col:red]][[img:icon_arrow_down]][[/img]] Sobriety causes health loss over time[[/col]]
A mixture of chemicals that becomes a fiery liquid that is difficult to put out, conveniently packaged in a small clay pot.
Crack open the djinn vessel, release the Djinn held within.
Crack open the djinn vessel, release the Djinn held within.
Crack open the djinn vessel, release the Djinn held within.
Crack open the djinn vessel, release the Djinn held within.
Crack open the djinn vessel, release the Djinn held within.
Give a Djinn too much freedom and they will start thinking dangerous thoughts.
The magician utters a blessing onto the weapons of his allies, imbuing their attacks with the magic of the elements.
Conjured by an Arabyan magician, a magical illusion exploits his enemy's most inner desires, distracting them from their foe.
Conjured by an Arabyan magician, a magical illusion exploits his enemy's most inner desires, distracting them from their foe.
Bright beams of burning energy leap from the wizard's eyes and scythe through all before him.
Bright beams of burning energy leap from the wizard's eyes and scythe through all before him.
Commanding the desert spirit of Da'ru'de, the sorcerer engulfs his foes in a swirling cloud of choking sand and dust.
Commanding the desert spirit of Da'ru'de, the sorcerer engulfs his foes in a swirling cloud of choking sand and dust.
The wizard turns the ground into bottomless quicksand, dragging any unfortunates down into the abyss.
The wizard turns the ground into bottomless quicksand, dragging any unfortunates down into the abyss.
As if possessed by a Fire Efreet, the caster conjures scorching flames from his hands to burn his enemies to a crisp.
As if possessed by a Fire Efreet, the caster conjures scorching flames from his hands to burn his enemies to a crisp.
Channeling the immense powers of the Djinn through his own body, the sorcerer lays a terrible curse upon his foes.
Channeling the immense powers of the Djinn through his own body, the sorcerer lays a terrible curse upon his foes.
Summoned creatures exist in this world on borrowed time, disappearing back to the winds from whence they came.
Summoned creatures exist in this world on borrowed time, disappearing back to the winds from whence they came.
The Sustaining Magic that holds these subjects in the mortal world has failed. After their spirit gets ripped out of their temporal form, nothing is left but an empty husk.
When a daemon exists in the mortal plane, their power waxes and wanes with the Winds of Magic, making them highly unpredictable foes.
The Sustaining Magic that holds these subjects in the mortal world has failed. After their spirit gets ripped out of their temporal form, nothing is left but an empty husk.
When a daemon exists in the mortal plane, their power waxes and wanes with the Winds of Magic, making them highly unpredictable foes.
Albion's warriors are known for their fickle nature in fights. As long as their belief in themselves is unbroken, they attack with savage, unrelenting bravery.
Albion's warriors are known for their moody nature in fights. When facing a superior foe or finding themselves on the losing side of a battle, they can lose heart quickly.

Woad Paint is applied by druids. It uses the excess magic of the area to protect the warrior whose skin is painted with it. The stronger the winds of magic in an area, the more effective the paint will be.
As long as this unit isn't injured too much, they are able to savagely charge their enemies with devastating effect.
The magic of Albion conjures the famous mists of its homeland, enveloping allied warriors, protecting them from projectiles.
The mage calls upon the gods of hunting and battle to grant his allies additional strength and skill.
Dying Warriors are granted a second chance as the spell of the truthsayer mends their deadly wounds and allows them to return to battle.
A barrier of shimmering light protects the warriors from magic and flame alike.
The booming voice of the truthsayer fills the mind of an enemy, robbing them of the concentration necessary to operate ranged weapons.
The voice of the truthsayer is heard in the minds of his warriors, invoking their sense of honor and giving them unwavering hope and toughness even in the most desperate of situations.
The Truthsayer conjures a flock of magical birds which will fly straight into the enemy formations, bringing doom to those they collide with.
Trees live for thousands of years and have very long memories. When called to fight, centuries of pent-up wrath are unleashed.
The mage calls upon the gods of hunting and battle to grant his allies the ability to fight with unnatural strength and fearsome savagery.
Dying Warriors are granted a second chance as the spell of the truthsayer mends their deadly wounds and allows them to return to battle.
A barrier of shimmering light protects the warriors from magic and flame alike.
The booming voice of the truthsayer fills the mind of an enemy, robbing them of the concentration necessary to operate ranged weapons.
The voice of the truthsayer is heard in the minds of his warriors, invoking their sense of honor and giving them unwavering hope even in the most desperate of situations.
The Truthsayer conjures a flock of magic bird which will fly straight into the enemy formations, bringing doom to those they collide with.
These unnatural creatures require magic to exist - the more the better. If the winds of magic blow strongly, they are more stable on the battlefield.
Fen Hulks are embodiments of the corrupted lands of Albion. Wherever they go, the land is corrupted into muddy bogs which greatly hinder their enemies.
Only the best warleaders mastered the art of motivating their warriors to fight even harder with nothing more than a single, mighty cry of defiance.
Those who stand against Morrigan have a feeling of their impending doom. Some say it is simply a glimpse into their near future.
Morrigan's allies fight harder in her presence because they know about the importance of the battle if even the Phantom Queen takes part in it.
Morrigan's flock of crows follows her everywhere and will attack each and any enemy coming close to her.
Howling Shields are a speciality of the warriors of the Fir Domain. They are constructed in such a way that air passing through the shields produces a frightening howling sound.
Morrigan's ravens cloud the skies, circling above the battlefield and attacking every enemy who dares to take to the air.
Morrigan conjures a flock of magical birds which will fly straight into the enemy formations, bringing doom to those they collide with.
Morrigan's flock of ravens follows her everywhere and will attack each and any enemy coming close to her, aiming for their eyes and attacking them without pause or remorse.
It is said that Huntresses who follow Morrigan have to hunt an eagle to obtain its eyes for themselves, allowing them to hit the most difficult targets from afar.
These warriors put their trust into their gods and will attack relentlessly without fear unless they are decimated enough to lose some of that trust in divine protection.
If we can't save the world, no one can.
Imperfect Shield of the Old Ones
Dural Durak has more insight into the secrets of the Old Ones than any other human alive, but even his knowledge is but an incomplete reflection of the truth, tainted by the passing of the ages.
The Staff of Dural Durak twists the winds of magic in a unique way, making it difficult for enemy casters to utilize them.
Usually, it takes preparation and a lengthy ritual to produce fenbeasts, but Dural Durak is able to create them during battles when needed. None of the other Truthsayers knows how.

One of the few surviving artifacts of the Old Ones still in the hands of the people of Albion, this amulet unleashes a wave of magic into the air, healing its wearer and saturating the area with magic. After each activation, the item has to rest for a long time until it has recharged enough to be used again.
Through sheer willpower, they will continue fighting with their body ravaged by wounds until the independence of Albion is protected and secured.
The strongest Giant of Albion is almost as revered as a minor deity by Albion's inhabitants. His appearence of the battlefield raises the spirit of all who fight on his side.

Just like most Albion Giants, Bologs intellect leaves a lot to desire. His name is the only word he speaks and doubles as his warcry when Bologs gets angry. And you really don't want Bologs to get angry.

In their time as mercenaries, lost in the lands of Tilea, Hengus the Druid would guide Bologs and his brother. Hengus is far too old now to take to the battlefield himself, but he will still prepare the giant brothers with the last of his feeble magic for the battles ahead.
These warriors have focused on proving their worth on the battlefield. As long as their will is unbroken, they will push themselves beyond their limits.
The Fimir will do anything for but a moment of attention from the Dark Gods. No act of bravery is too foolhardy, no act of cruelty too savage.
Under the Eyes of the Gods
Maybe the only threat to a halfling that might make them fight harder is a threat to their food.
Who doesn't fight also doesn't eat!
Nothing like a snack mid-battle to re-invigourate a halfling!
If we can't save the food, then why are we even fighting?
Not as dangerous as the breath of an adult, but it is still advised to avoid being its target.
Shoot faster, we have plenty more where that came from!
Get your broken weapons fixed, your armour upgraded or your hat patched.
The tactical burning of special tobacco obscures the unit and its allies, making them harder to hit with missiles. It also temporarily numbs the pain of warriors in range.
An ancient scourge of the living has been unleashed and only the mindless can escape the creeping feeling of desperation and horror caused by the Hand of Nagash.
To be honest it is mostly executioner. Everyone who stands against Nagash is guilty by default.
Focussing the winds of death around him, the Hand of Nagash can unleash a devastating wave of destruction.

The Hand of Nagash has strapped the torso of a most hated foe to his halberd. Though the name of this unlucky person is lost to time, it is said that the terror and pain of his last moments still radiates from his tortured remains.
When the Hand of Nagash fades, the forbidden runes of this Blade activate, using the life of his enemies to preserve his unholy existence.
The disciples of Nagash spread his influence wherever they go. And where the power of Nagash is on the rise, the dead won't find rest easily.
Buried under the sands, countless forgotten legions wait for Nagash to call them to arms once again.
Buried under the sands, countless forgotten legions wait for Nagash to call them to arms once again.

The towering frame of a skeletal giant can be seen far and wide on the battlefield. As such they are perfectly suited to serve as a conduit to channel the dark magic from the necromancer to his troops, anchoring them in the mortal world.
Larenscheld resurrected the Dread King in exchange for immortality - and he received it, in a way. However, it came in a different form than he expected.
Larenscheld has been granted the ability to call forth vengeful spirits in the shape of skulls from the realms beyond the mortal veil to torment the living.
Even if the body perishes, his mind and magic will persist to haunt those who bested him.
The mortal body is but a shell that holds back true greatness and may be discarded at will.
Nothing revitalizes Trolls like a little snack. A gobbo or two nearby just come in handy when your Trolls need additional motivation.
Night Trolls are known to make noises sounding like mocking laughter while tearing their enemies apart. Those who witness these sounds can be easily intimidated by them.
Almost unbearable smell. Don't get close!
Hitting that skin with a sword is like hitting a mountain with a toothpick! No wonder these trolls are so much more confident than their brethren.
This creature reeks of death, rotten corpses, feces and worse. Being near it is almost intolerable.
Hunger can be a greater motivation than any other. The Monsterhorde will storm towards the enemy, and nothing can stop it!
The boss can give limited orders to the trolls that are the longest under his influence. This order makes them swing low and wide, effective against smaller targets.
Bosses Order: Squish the Little Ones!
Bosses can give limited orders to the trolls that are the longest under his influence. This order makes them fight more cautiously and protect their vital organs.
The boss can give limited orders to the trolls that are the longest under his influence. This order makes them chase tirelessly after faster targets.
Bosses Order: Get the Fast Ones!
The boss can give limited orders to the trolls that are the longest under his influence. This order makes them chase tirelessly after faster targets.

These Trolls are camouflaged in forests by their natural coloration. However, they are too stupid to understand the concept of an ambush. Their smell and the noise they make will give their position away once someone is close enough.
The regenerative ability of Bile Trolls is mostly occupied by keeping their many afflictions at bay. This means that wounds Bile Trolls receive are healing much slower compared to other Trolls.

Bile Trolls are feared by all, even by their famously stupid kin. They aren't feared for their combat prowess though, instead, no one wants to get near them and risk infection - not even their allies.
This is what happens if an already angry Troll feels provoked, frustrated, threatened or bored.
Lava Trolls are filled with unbearable heat. Those getting too close are affected by this heat, their flesh burning in the presence of this twisted troll species.

The twisted effects of their warpstone changed skin made the skin of these creatures highly resistant to any damage, especially magic. They don't feel pain and will not run before the their unnatural armour is broken.
Breathe in, release, breathe out, repeat.
Heat of the desert, the sand is on my face, without accomplice the soldier knows no disgrace...
Taken by Fatandira from the tomb of the Liche Lord Karitamen in the Borderlands, this pair of Nehekharan Khopeshes magically enhance their owner's combat skills, and weaken anyone struck by them.

One of the Golden Magus' most infamous creations, this fiery curved sword is kept most of the time inside a jar filled with a slimy orange solution. When drawn out of it, the sword catches a mystical fire that the Magus' uses for battle, theatrics and summoning Djinn spirits. Contrary to popular belief, the ship is named after the sword.
Magical Support: Piercing Bolts of Ruin
Orders the Flaming Scimitar's Fire Efreets to unleash a barrage of burning bolts upon your enemies.
Orders the Flaming Scimitar's Tempest Djinns to conjure a potent torrent of curved windswords upon the battlefield.
The dusty and unforgivable wind of the south, it brings with it the fury and the sweltering heat of the desert.
The cool and protective wind of the north, it blows away the evil and wrongness in the skies and shields all from harm.
A column of churning fire erupts from the battlefield, causing much destruction!
Searing flames burst from the caster, burning everything around them.
The power the Golden Magus wields comes at a price. If his concentration wanes during battle, the Djinn under his control will sense his weakness and attempt to turn the Magus' power against himself.
“A good story, you don't really write. It was always there. You just uncover it.”
Through his perseverance and determination, Glibfoot's tall tales have now become a reality, and as such he now inspires the Halflings following him to deeds of legend.

No one is quite sure of how a Halfling adventurer has gotten his hands onto a Druchii Repeater Crossbow, and what's even stranger, the weapon is enchanted with the White Wind of Magic. Could any of Glibfoot's braggadocious tales be actually true?

Glibfoot claims that the High Elves of Ulthuan gifted him this small magical blade as thanks for single-handedly defeating a Greenskin invasion of the Asur Homeland. In reality, it is a trinket "borrowed" from the chambers of an Elven Archmage, an enchanted letter opener with the ability to magically "open" almost anything... armour included.
So long as the Master Chef is out of combat, he will keep cooking revitalising food for his fellow Halflings.
A little bit of Rhya’s fancy
The Rumster Clan of Halflings are known to make anything put in a pie taste good... even each other
One of the longshanks brought these mean little buggers from Lustria... Why don't you have a taste?
So you want to get my food? WELL, CHOKE ON IT!
